metadata.name: Xel I-II #1
metadata.description:
We‚Äôve always known wallet addresses as strings of letters and numbers, Dry, soulless data, yet always present.
But what if this presence could breathe?

In the enhanced, living version of "Season One", we revisit that same idea, transforming the blockchain‚Äôs most essential elements into evolving pixelated lifeforms.
Each artwork is still generated from the wallet address (`fxminter`) and the token‚Äôs hash (`fxhash`), but the project pulses with a new kind of energy this time.

### What‚Äôs new in this evolved version:

üï∞ A Magical Clock
A real-time clock has been embedded into the artwork. One that only ticks forward with each new mint.
Each minted token captures a unique minute in time, held eternally by its collector.
This enchanted clock is not merely decorative. It holds a secret that will only be fully unveiled in "Season Two".

üß© A Fragment of the Bigger Picture
Alongside the creature, every mint now receives a Roman numeral representing its mint number and a coordinate, marking its position in a hidden puzzle.
Each token is a piece of a larger design; together, these fragments will reconstruct the gateway to the next season.

üß¨ Multiple Perspectives, One Identity
The core pixel creature, still generated uniquely from your wallet and hash, now appears in three views:

* a breathing 2D form rendered in real time,
* a puzzled isometric shape,
* and a miniature preview of the final Season Two puzzle form, hinting at what‚Äôs to come.
  Your identity is no longer shown from a single angle, it‚Äôs a multidimensional expression.

üé® Colors from the Hash, Signatures from the Wallet
Like in the original version, all color palettes are derived directly from the hash. No two are alike.
And, as always, your wallet address is subtly signed beneath the artwork, a permanent mark of authorship.

---

This is not Season Two.
This is Season One: Alive, an evolved, living version of the original.
It preserves everything that made the first release special, but adds movement, time, spatial positioning, and hints of the next chapter.

If Season One was a spark, this version is its flame.
Only holders of these tokens will be able to step fully into Season Two and witness the transformation of their piece into its final narrative form.
Until then, this is your moment. Your pixel, your minute, your breath in the story.

Reptile ü¶é
----------
Made by p5.js
s = save

metadata.name: impossible cathedrals #283
metadata.description:
When the Impressionists first exhibited their work, they derided as lunatics by the art establishment. The vitriol then -- "wallpaper in its embryonic state is more finished than that seascape" (referring to Impression: sunrise by Monet) -- reminds me of criticism that generative art, and the NFT world more generally, are subject to now. "Impossible cathedrals" is a tribute to rebels who dare to see the world differently. 

Since generative art is often criticized as cold and austere, I took this as a challenge to reproduce the spirit of impressionism. Impossible cathedrals -- interwoven arches that cannot exist in reality -- hint at some of the favorite subjects of the impressionists.

The title alludes to Italo Calvino's novel Invisible Cities, a rebel in another context. Other artists who I had in mind during creation: the Japanese woodblock printing artists Kawase Hasui and Hiroshi Yoshida; American painter JAM Whistler.

Impossible cathedrals was written in p5.js using elements of code by eeedg (thanks)

metadata.name: Schwere See #179
metadata.description:
Schwere See (...which is german for "Heavy Seas") this work creates completely generative ocean worlds between the real and the surreal. what is real? when do we feel reality? i guess as with many other things, we feel reality best when we're deprived of it. That might be the reason why it never ceases to fascinate us to both exaggerate and abstract nature and reality - maybe even at the same time. that's where this work tries to go... giving my best to create realistic looking waves out of hmm... thin electron-gas..., and then disrupt those from realism by unnaturally exaggerating waveforms and abstracting the display to a few colors and lines - ...well, not so few of the latter, actually ;-) beware: this needs a good GPU (at least here in 2023) to properly run in realtime. stills can still be rendered on a low end machine with on-board graphics, but for realtime playing you'd need some proper dedicated graphics card. and of course it wont run fast (or maybe not all) on your mobile phone (except maybe on a very high end device). the different mints vary in wave shape, color, camera view, animation speed, aspect ratio, frame style, hatching density, field of view, and more. some color schemes are based on pre-chosen palettes (slightly varied though), but others are wildly random-generated. there's always some risk in randomness, but lets give the error some chance to surprise us - this is one of the many benefits of generative art. as generative art can do so much more than just generate/show an image i feel almost obliged to add the possibility to animate/inteact. however, this extra control shall not be chosen without some considerations. you don't want a strobingly wild animation above your fireplace or in a doctors waiting room. nor is it motion-wise very inspiring to have subtle image stills hanging in a dancefloor. so, by default when in animation mode (-key) the scene is very slowly and steadily changing - some pieces faster, some slower. however, by pressing you can toggle to a sped up animation of waves, clouds, and scene rotation. btw, going faster in nav-mode also speeds up the wave animation. (...so be careful when you accelerate! the ocean is not a ponyfarm.) mouse/keyboard functions: ..........rotate view .........zoom in/out ...............start animation (or append '&AnimEnable=1' to the url) +<1><2><3><4>...make png screenshot in 1/2/3/4-fold resolution

...................same as +<3> ...................toggle nav-mode - navigate/fly through scene /.........accelerate in nav-mode /.......decelerate in nav-mode /.......rotate left in nav-mode /......rotate right in nav-mode ...................fast animation mode (speeds up animation) some technical info: technically this is a raymarched scene. the distance field of the waves is constructed my many localized rotations on many different scales. for the hatching no actual lines are being drawn. it is archieved by applying periodic functions in world-position-space as halftone patterns to the actual image color. the frequency of these halftone-functions thereby depending on screen-position-derivatives.

metadata.name: White Mountain Winter #5
metadata.description:
White Mountain Winter is collaboration between myself and the machine to describe scenes that are real, or were. Yet perhaps now foreign, or out of time, or far away. I provide the seed of a dream I remember, and trust the machine to help make it real again.

I grew up in a town much like some of these, homes dispersed throughout the valley beneath the shadows of the mountains rising around. This is a tribute to the memory of wintertime in that place; bleak, cold, grey, with the light seemingly always fading. Yet at the same time, the feeling of calm, solace, peace resonating through. Exposed to the mountain elements, yet protected by them. A delicate arrangement, but essential.

The seed of magic I remember is present in the experience of falling snow at dusk. Large flakes tumbling down and blanketing everything, no end in sight. The most striking thing is the silence. The fallen snow absorbing all distraction, insisting that your focus be sharpened to a singularity; right there, right then.

---
- Best rendered in Chrome browser (best performance, & canvas blur - please be patient :)
- Made with p5js
- Press "s" to save png

metadata.name: [fxhashturnsone] 2022 A Generative Odyssey #281
metadata.description:
ü™êüåå‚ú®

2022 A Generative Odyssey (Story of a traveler)

A simple space landscape generator üèû
Allows some exploration for curious ones üì°
Don't forget to press "4" to take a panoramic picture üì∏ü§≥

üï≥üß≠üõ∞



-----
* Technics *

- JavaScript / ThreeJS / WebGL
- Pure code / no external assets
- Interactive / orbitable
- 8 scenes with unlimited possible variations
- 5 capture / screenshot modes 8K+

-----
* Controls *

Left click / touch + drag : orbit around center of interest
Wheel/pinch : zoom in/out
Keyboard "R" : enable automatic rotation of view

Keyboard "1" : PNG capture the current view at same resolution / ratio 
Keyboard "2" : PNG capture view as square 4320x4320
Keyboard "3" : PNG capture at best resolution 8K (7680x4320)
Keyboard "4" : PNG capture as panoramic view (8192x2304)
Keyboard "5" : PNG capture as super-panoramic (10650x3000)

-----
* URL modifier *

"&r=1"
enables auto rotation of view (equivalent to "R" key press)

-----
* Mint details *

- Mint preview / capture is PNG 1920x1920

-----
@HAL09999 ‚Äì May/November 2022

metadata.name: Return to Apophenia #179
metadata.description:
Fxhash turns one!
Revenue from initial sales divided 50% 40% 10% between Savepakistan, Processing Foundation and the artist.

Apophenia was my first project on fxhash. It seemed fitting to return to this concept for my anniversary mint and recreate it anew, employing many of the skills I have learned over the last year.

It has some fun interaction...

Mouse click in the centre of a hexagon to rotate that hexagon.
Hexagons have 1,2,3 or 6 unique rotations.

On the keyboard:
'c' to regenerate the work with the colours of the palette rotated
'r' to recreate the work with re-randomised hexagons
't' to change the edge tiles so that the complete image becomes a seamlessly tiling rectangle
'y' to generate a symmetrical image with the same scale and colour palette - this will use different hexagons from the original image and any further interaction will act on the original image, not the symmetrical pattern, which almost certainly won't tile

keys 2 through 9 to render at increasing resolutions

's' to save a .png of the current canvas

26 palettes with random rotations + 12 unique hexagons + 10 hexagon combinations + lots of scale and layout possibilities = virtual infinity

Created with p5.js

metadata.name: Absorbed #423
metadata.description:
A collaboration between leading British high-end audio brand KEF, generative artist hieroglyphica, and creative studio Parameta, Absorbed embodies the process of noise becoming high-fidelity sound through KEF‚Äôs Metamaterial Absorption Technology (MAT‚Ñ¢). 

MAT‚Ñ¢ makes the KEF sound what it is: absorbing unwanted distortion to deliver pure, accurate sound exactly as the artist intended. Inspired by this intricacy, Absorbed illustrates pseudorandom networks of patterns, slowly emerging and transforming into the maze-like form of MAT‚Ñ¢. Clarity is revealed, noise is absorbed ‚Äì high-fidelity is found.

The noise fields used in Absorbed are of two distinct types: conventional gradient noise and ‚Äúsinusoidal‚Äù noise, an original algorithm developed for this series. The use of animation as artistic medium reflects the artists‚Äô belief that no single frame can capture the full range of complexity found in the tension between sound and noise, and lets collectors observe for themselves this ever-shifting dialogue. A more extensive discussion of the algorithms used in Absorbed can be found in hieroglyphica‚Äôs companion article on fx(text).

- spacebar will pause and resume the animation
- s will save a still image of the current frame
- technically minded collectors can consult the index.html file for info on how to render and save high-resolution images
- use of hardware acceleration in Chrome may impact performance

Founded by BBC engineer Raymond Cooke in 1961, KEF is a leading British innovator of high-end audio products including HiFi speakers, subwoofers, architectural speakers, wireless speaker-systems, and headphones. Find out more at kef.com or visit our Discord at discord.com/invite/u48Z9yjY2q.

metadata.name: FairyCells #355
metadata.description:
FairyCells is a series created by a generative system, displaying shapes, between 1 and 10, made up of three different color palettes. 
Cells cannot cross each other, and are composed of a flat tint and/or a hatch system.

You can right-click to download an SVG file of the NFT or press ¬´¬†E¬†¬ª to export as png (3401x3401px)

Moreover, the digital version can exist as a physical piece.
Owning the NFT gives the right to order, in addition, a 30x30cm plotter drawing of it. More information about it here: https://nft.julienespagnon.fr/fairy-cells.
You can see some test examples plotted in the google form: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1FO3Umh49qmJApZAlQgZ46a2y421QYEWIW8r72nLrW4Q/edit

Work by Julien Espagnon - 2021/2022

metadata.name: Glomularus #43
metadata.description:
Glomularus is an exploration in generative, artificial life forms. The project is an extension of my Protobyte series, begun in 2004.

Driven by Verlet icosahedra and responsive tendrils, Glomulari live in a spherical virtual ecosystem (V-eco) enhanced through user interaction.

Interaction:

Mouse/Trackpad:
  drag -> camera rotation
  drag + CMD/CTR -> camera pan
  scroll wheel/pinch -> camera zoom

Key Input:
  1-9: add acceleration
  -, +: reduce | increase V-eco sphere radius
  f, g: reduce | increase fog
  p: screen capture

Tip:
To decrease creature acceleration, reduce V-eco sphere radius

Note:
Please post your favorite Glomularus screen captures
TW: @iragreenberg
IG: @greenberg.ira

Built with Three.js, PByte.js, TypeScript, Node

metadata.name: Prismatic Thickets #904
metadata.description:
'Prismatic Thickets' is a pure generative painting algorithm; it's not animated nor interactive, but does goes further than any related painting program I've written prior. I created a very large and affordable edition with the hope that collectors can freely explore the emergent potential of the algorithm. 

The Burn (Tuesday, Aug. 23, 2022, 12:05AM UTC):
96 hours after minting opens, all unminted tokens will be burned.

p -> screen capture


Background:
I thought it might be helpful to offer a little background as to why I'm so excited about 'Prismatic Thickets'. 

I began my professional life as a painter; both my degrees are in painting (MFA '92, BFA '89). I got into computing immediately upon completing my MFA. At first, the digital work was to pay the bills (early digital design/illustration/production work.) Soon though, I grew pretty obsessed and started reading computing/software manuals cover-to-cover (yes, dork). At the same time, I was painting, primarily landscapes (plein air).

The plein air painting transitioned from landscapes, to trees, to just branches/leaves, which eventually led to abstract work based primarily on related natural patterns. I also began coding at this time (1994-95). One of my first creative programming projects was based on one of my painted patterned abstractions. I remember the first time I ran my program, saw the coded painting emerge and knew my life would never be the same. This led to an even deeper dive reading programming/math/CS theory textbooks (even bigger dork). 

I quickly realized there were very few programming references for people like me. This eventually led to me writing 3 Processing books and building numerous university creative coding programs around the country. Though this period was exciting, there still remained a major disconnect for me. I hadn't really put my painting background together with my coding background. Obviously, we didn't have marketplaces like fx(hash) back then, to support generative artists. So I essentially took refuge in the ivory tower, creating a gazillion demos, courses, tutorials, workshops, etc.

The worldwide interest in NFT's, especially in the generative space with Art Blocks and fx(hash) has created a venue for creative coders I honestly never thought was possible. It's completely rejuvenated my passion for creative coding and helped me reconnect with some creative coding OG's and many wonderful new artists. So many of the projects I see on Art Blocks and fx(hash) bring me back to the early days and passionate excitement of discovering the generative power of creative coding.

Most of my NFT projects have been fairly dense physics-based experiments. Many of these leverage a codebase I've developed over decades, which I've been slowly porting from Java/P3, C++/OF to TypeScript/three.js. What I hadn't (re)explored was what got me excited about creative coding to begin with: generative painting.


Made with: TypeScript, three.js, PByte.js, Node

In memory of Robert Slutzky

metadata.name: Polar Grid #785
metadata.description:
Polar Grid is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022.

This is a study of color, motion, and composition, and an homage to cinema as an artform. Colorful shapes overlap and pulse in a ever repeating dance. An abstracted movie experience. Each color palette in the series (except one) is inspired by a different film director (if you want a real challenge, see how many you can guess without looking at the feature names).

The palettes were extracted from movie stills or movie posters and fine tuned by hand. As often, I have to thank independent tool makers for their indirect help. My gratitude goes to David Aerne for FarbV√©lo and Fabrizio Bianchi for Coolors.

The code for Polar Grid is based on early iterations of what ultimately became my carat series. Both projects come from the same fascination for color as a system, even though I used a different approach here. You could call this a carat prequel.

The animation is done using a technique called polar noise. This makes it so the motion of all elements ends up repeating in the same amount of time. This is useful for generating motion that loops perfectly while still appearing organic. In this particular case, the animation repeats every œÄ √ó 100 seconds.

A challenge in building any generative system is to find the right balance between coherence and variety. I designed the system with the large edition size in mind. During development I generated hundreds of iterations and tweaked my code to make sure that every iteration is truly unique and fits the overall aesthetic of the collection.

I truly hope you will enjoy your own little abstract movie.

‚Äî Rapha√´l de Courville


Released: July 6th 2022

Medium: p5.js, html canvas, css

Reference: sk220621


**About the artist**

Rapha√´l de Courville is a generative artist, streamer, and educator. His artistic work is an exploration of generative systems, patterns, interactivity, and time. Born in Paris, he lives and works in Berlin.


**Instructions**

- Click/Tap or press SPACEBAR to play and pause the animation

In Fullscreen mode (desktop only):
- Press UP or DOWN arrows to adjust image quality (Note: this can affect performance)
- Press F to hide/show the browser UI
